title: 103_hr1472
content:
The Act is titled the "Assault Weapons Limitation Act of 1993" and defines key terms. The "Assault Weapons Limitation Act of 1993" defines the term 'assault weapon' as specific firearms and 'form 4473' as a prescribed form by the Secretary. The Secretary may recommend the addition or deletion of firearms designated as assault weapons in the Assault Weapons Limitation Act of 1993. The Secretary may recommend adding or removing firearms classified as assault weapons in the Assault Weapons Limitation Act of 1993. SEC. 3 states additional unlawful acts related to assault weapons. Section 922 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to prohibit the transfer or possession of assault weapons, with exceptions for government entities and pre-existing lawful possession. It is also unlawful to sell, ship, or deliver an assault weapon without the completion of form 4473. It is unlawful to purchase, possess, or accept delivery of an assault weapon without completing form 4473. However, individuals who owned assault weapons before the effective date are exempt until regulations are prescribed within 90 days. If purchasing from a non-licensed dealer, both buyer and seller must maintain a record on form 4473. The Secretary must prescribe regulations within 90 days of enactment regarding form 4473 completion. Completion of form 4473 is required when purchasing an assault weapon, and the form must be available from licensed dealers. SEC. 4. PENALTIES.

Amends Section 924 of title 18, United States Code to increase penalties for firearm violations, including imprisonment for 10 years for assault weapons. Introduces a new subsection imposing fines or imprisonment for knowingly violating section 922(t).

SEC. 5. DISABILITY.

Amends Section 922(g)(1) of title 18, United States Code to include violations of section 922(t) as a disqualifying factor.

SEC. 6. STUDY BY THE ATTORNEY GENERAL. The Attorney General will conduct a study to investigate the impact of the Act and its amendments on violent and drug trafficking crime over 18 months. A detailed report will be submitted to Congress within 30 months of the Act's enactment. The Act and its amendments will take effect 30 days after enactment and will be repealed 3 years after the effective date.
